docs.title: devenv
docs.text: A sophisticated containerized development environment template with Claude AI integration.

docs.title: What is devenv?
docs.text:
devenv is a cookiecutter template that generates production-ready Python projects with:

  • 3-Layer Architecture - Clean separation of domain, adapters, and services
  • Dual Interfaces - REST API (FastAPI) and CLI (Typer) out of the box
  • Modern Python Tooling - uv package manager, hatch-vcs versioning
  • VS Code Dev Containers - Fully containerized development environment
  • Claude AI Integration - Pre-configured agents and MCP servers
  • BEACON Framework - Pragmatic, artifact-driven development methodology

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Install cookiecutter
pip install cookiecutter

# Generate a new project
cookiecutter gh:darth-veitcher/devenv

# Follow the prompts...

That's it! You'll have a fully configured Python project ready for development.

docs.title: What You Get
docs.text:
When you generate a project, you receive:

my-project/
├── src/my_project/          # 3-layer Python package
│   ├── domain/              # Business entities
│   ├── adapters/            # Repository implementations
│   ├── services/            # Application logic
│   ├── api/                 # FastAPI REST API
│   └── cli/                 # Typer CLI
├── tests/                   # pytest test suite
├── docs/                    # MkDocs documentation
├── .devcontainer/           # VS Code Dev Container
├── .claude/                 # Claude AI agent configs
├── project-management/      # BEACON framework artifacts
├── justfile                 # Development commands
├── pyproject.toml           # Modern Python packaging
└── docker-compose.yml       # Container orchestration

docs.title: 1. Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/darth-veitcher/devenv.git
cd devenv

docs.title: 2. Install Dependencies
docs.text:
The template itself doesn't have Python dependencies, but to test it:

pip install cookiecutter

docs.title: 3. Test Generation
docs.text:
# Generate a test project
cookiecutter . --no-input -o /tmp

# Verify it works
cd /tmp/my-project
uv sync --all-extras
uv run pytest

docs.title: Template Files
docs.text:
Files in {{cookiecutter.project_slug}}/ are templated:

# Uses Jinja2 syntax
{{ cookiecutter.project_name }}
{{ cookiecutter.author_name }}

docs.title: Root Files
docs.text:
Files at the root of devenv/ are for the template itself:

  • cookiecutter.json - Template variables
  • hooks/ - Pre/post generation scripts
  • docs/ - Template documentation (this site)

docs.title: Escaping Just Variables
docs.text:
In justfiles, escape just variables:

# Wrong - cookiecutter interprets {{ARGS}}
serve *ARGS:
    my_app serve {{ARGS}}

# Correct - escape for cookiecutter
serve *ARGS:
    my_app serve {{ '{{' }}ARGS{{ '}}' }}

docs.title: Generate and Test
docs.text:
# Clean test
rm -rf /tmp/test-project

# Generate
cookiecutter . --no-input \
  -o /tmp \
  project_name="test-project"

# Test
cd /tmp/test-project
uv sync --all-extras
uv run pytest
uv run mkdocs build

docs.title: Test Different Options
docs.text:
# Different Python version
cookiecutter . --no-input \
  -o /tmp \
  python_version="3.11"

# Different port
cookiecutter . --no-input \
  -o /tmp \
  app_port="3000"

docs.title: project_name
docs.text:
The human-readable name of your project.

project_name [My Project]: My Awesome App
  • Appears in documentation
  • Used in CLI help text
  • Displayed in API docs

docs.title: project_slug
docs.text:
URL and package-safe version of the project name.

project_slug [my-awesome-app]:
  • Auto-generated from project_name (lowercase, hyphens)
  • Used for package directory: src/my_awesome_app/
  • Used for git repository name
  • Used in Docker image names

Tip

Usually accept the default derived from project_name.

docs.title: project_description
docs.text:
Short description of your project.

project_description [A sophisticated multi-layer...]: A task management API
  • Appears in pyproject.toml
  • Shown in API documentation
  • Used in README

docs.title: author_name & author_email
docs.text:
Your details for package metadata.

author_name [Your Name]: Jane Developer
author_email [your.email@example.com]: jane@example.com
  • Listed in pyproject.toml
  • Appears in LICENSE
  • Used for git configuration suggestions

docs.title: github_username
docs.text:
Your GitHub username.

github_username [yourusername]: janedeveloper
  • Used in documentation URLs
  • Repository links in pyproject.toml
  • MkDocs configuration

docs.title: python_version
docs.text:
Minimum Python version required.

python_version [3.12]:
  • Sets requires-python in pyproject.toml
  • Determines Docker base image
  • Affects type hint features available

Note

Python 3.12+ is recommended for best type hint support.

docs.title: Customization

docs.title: After Generation
docs.text: Generated projects are fully yours to modify. There's no "magic" - everything is standard Python.

docs.title: Change the Architecture
docs.text:
The 3-layer architecture is a starting point. You can:

Add more layers:

src/my_project/
├── domain/
├── adapters/
├── services/
├── api/
├── cli/
├── jobs/          # Add background jobs
└── integrations/  # Add external integrations

Simplify for small projects:

src/my_project/
├── models.py      # Combined domain
├── db.py          # Combined adapters
├── api.py         # Combined presentation
└── main.py

docs.title: Add a Database
docs.text:
1. Add dependencies to pyproject.toml:
dependencies = [
    # ... existing deps
    "sqlalchemy>=2.0.0",
    "asyncpg>=0.29.0",  # For PostgreSQL
]
  1. Create a database adapter:
# src/my_project/adapters/repositories/postgres.py
from sqlalchemy.ext.asyncio import AsyncSession

class PostgresExampleRepository(ExampleRepository):
    def __init__(self, session: AsyncSession):
        self._session = session

    async def save(self, entity: ExampleEntity) -> ExampleEntity:
        # ... implementation
  1. Update dependency injection in api/main.py

docs.title: Add Authentication
docs.text:
1. Add dependencies:
dependencies = [
    # ... existing deps
    "python-jose[cryptography]>=3.3.0",
    "passlib[bcrypt]>=1.7.4",
]
  1. Create auth module:
# src/my_project/infrastructure/auth.py
from fastapi import Depends, HTTPException
from fastapi.security import OAuth2PasswordBearer

oauth2_scheme = OAuth2PasswordBearer(tokenUrl="token")

async def get_current_user(token: str = Depends(oauth2_scheme)):
    # Verify token and return user
    ...
  1. Add to routes:
@app.get("/protected")
async def protected_route(user = Depends(get_current_user)):
    return {"user": user.email}

docs.title: Add Background Tasks
docs.text:
1. Add Celery or similar:
dependencies = [
    "celery>=5.3.0",
    "redis>=5.0.0",
]
  1. Create tasks module:
# src/my_project/jobs/tasks.py
from celery import Celery

app = Celery("my_project")

@app.task
def process_entity(entity_id: str):
    # ... background processing

docs.title: Customize the CLI
docs.text:
Add new commands to cli/main.py:

@app.command()
def export(
    format: str = typer.Option("json", help="Export format"),
    output: Path = typer.Option("export.json", help="Output file"),
) -> None:
    """Export all entities."""
    entities = run_async(service.list_all())
    # ... export logic

docs.title: Add API Endpoints
docs.text:
Extend api/main.py:

@app.get("/entities", response_model=list[EntityResponse])
async def list_entities(
    skip: int = 0,
    limit: int = 100,
    service: ExampleService = Depends(get_example_service),
) -> list[Any]:
    """List all entities with pagination."""
    return await service.list_all(skip=skip, limit=limit)

docs.title: BEACON Framework
docs.text: Generated projects include the BEACON Framework - a pragmatic, artifact-driven development methodology.

docs.title: What is BEACON?
docs.text:
BEACON helps solo developers and small teams build software methodically:

  • **B**uild working software daily
  • **E**valuate ideas before building
  • **A**rchitect with reversibility
  • **C**ode in tracer bullets
  • **O**perate with simplicity
  • **N**avigate with clear documentation

docs.title: 1. Tracer Bullets
docs.text:
Build complete, minimal paths through your system that work end-to-end.

Day 1: Hardcoded response (proves plumbing)
Day 2: In-memory storage (proves logic)
Day 3: File storage (proves persistence)
Day 4: Database (production ready)

Each step delivers working software.

docs.title: 2. DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself)
docs.text: Every piece of knowledge has a single, authoritative representation.

docs.title: 3. Orthogonality
docs.text: Design independent components with minimal coupling.

docs.title: 4. Reversibility
docs.text: Make decisions that can be changed. Always have an escape hatch.

docs.title: 5. Simplicity
docs.text: The simplest thing that could possibly work. Complexity must earn its keep.

docs.title: Project Management Structure
docs.text:
Generated projects include:

project-management/
├── ADRs/                    # Architectural Decision Records
│   └── ADR-000-template.md
├── Background/              # Problem context
│   └── 00-problem-statement.md
├── Roadmap/                 # Development plan
│   └── README.md
└── Work/                    # Transient workspace

docs.title: ADRs (Architectural Decision Records)
docs.text:
Document significant technical decisions:

# ADR-001: Use PostgreSQL for persistence

## Status
Accepted

## Context
We need a database for production data storage.

## Decision
Use PostgreSQL via SQLAlchemy.

## Consequences
- Proven, reliable database
- Requires PostgreSQL installation
- Team familiar with SQL

docs.title: Problem Statement
docs.text:
Define why before how:

# Problem Statement

## Core Problem
Users cannot track their daily tasks efficiently.

## Target User
Solo developers managing personal projects.

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Create tasks in < 5 seconds
- [ ] View all tasks on single screen

docs.title: Roadmap
docs.text:
Track progress with tracer bullets:

## Tracer Bullet Progress

### Phase 1: Foundation
- [x] Bullet #1: Hardcoded response
- [x] Bullet #2: In-memory storage
- [ ] Bullet #3: File persistence

docs.title: Morning
docs.text:
1. Fix any broken windows (< 15 min)
  2. Review today's bullet goal
  3. Write acceptance test first

docs.title: During Session
docs.text:
1. Focus on ONE bullet only
  2. Write test → See fail → Make pass
  3. Verify previous bullets still work
  4. Commit with meaningful message

docs.title: End of Session
docs.text:
1. Update Roadmap with progress
  2. Note tomorrow's bullet
  3. Ask: "Would I sign this?"

docs.title: The Prime Directive
docs.text:
"Would I proudly sign my name to this?"

Every commit, every function, every decision should pass this test.

docs.title: Starting a New Feature
docs.text:
1. Create a bullet in the Roadmap
  2. Write the acceptance test
  3. Implement minimally
  4. Verify and commit

docs.title: Making Architectural Decisions
docs.text:
1. Document in an ADR
  2. Include context, decision, consequences
  3. Link from Roadmap

docs.title: Handling Technical Debt
docs.text:
Fix immediately if < 15 minutes, otherwise:

  1. Create an issue with deadline
  2. Add to Roadmap as a bullet
  3. Don't let it fester

docs.title: Docker Setup
docs.text: Generated projects include comprehensive Docker configuration for development and production.

docs.title: Files Overview
docs.text: File Purpose Dockerfile Production-ready multi-stage build docker-compose.yml Service orchestration .devcontainer/compose.yml Dev container services .devcontainer/compose-mcp.yml MCP server services

docs.title: Dockerfile
docs.text:
Multi-stage build optimized for size and security:

# Build stage
FROM python:3.12-slim AS builder
COPY --from=ghcr.io/astral-sh/uv:latest /uv /usr/local/bin/uv
WORKDIR /app
COPY pyproject.toml uv.lock ./
RUN uv sync --frozen --no-dev
COPY src/ src/

# Runtime stage
FROM python:3.12-slim AS runtime
RUN useradd --create-home --shell /bin/bash app
WORKDIR /app
COPY --from=builder --chown=app:app /app/.venv /app/.venv
COPY --from=builder --chown=app:app /app/src /app/src
USER app
ENV PATH="/app/.venv/bin:$PATH"
EXPOSE 8000
CMD ["python", "-m", "my_project.api.main"]

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Multi-stage - Small final image (~150MB vs ~1GB)
  • Non-root user - Security best practice
  • uv for speed - Fast dependency installation
  • Locked dependencies - Reproducible builds

docs.title: Production Services
docs.text:
docker-compose.yml:

services:
  app:
    build: .
    ports:
      - "8000:8000"
    environment:
      - DATABASE_URL=postgresql://postgres:postgres@db:5432/app
    depends_on:
      - db

  db:
    image: postgres:16-alpine
    environment:
      - POSTGRES_PASSWORD=postgres
      - POSTGRES_DB=app
    volumes:
      - postgres_data:/var/lib/postgresql/data

volumes:
  postgres_data:

      timeout: 10s
      retries: 3

docs.title: MCP Servers
docs.text: Generated projects include pre-configured Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers for enhanced AI capabilities.

docs.title: What is MCP?
docs.text: The Model Context Protocol allows AI assistants like Claude to interact with external tools and services. Think of it as giving Claude superpowers.

docs.title: context7
docs.text:
Documentation lookup and library reference

  • Returns relevant code examples
  • Understands library versions

docs.title: SearXNG
docs.text:
Privacy-respecting web search

> Search for Python async best practices 2024
  • No tracking
  • Multiple search engines
  • Returns structured results

docs.title: Crawl4AI
docs.text:
Web content extraction

> Fetch and summarize https://example.com/article
  • Converts pages to markdown
  • Extracts structured data
  • Handles JavaScript-rendered content

docs.title: Memgraph
docs.text:
Graph database operations

> Query the knowledge graph for related concepts
  • Cypher query language
  • Real-time graph operations
  • Built-in algorithms

docs.title: Playwright
docs.text:
Browser automation

> Take a screenshot of the homepage
  • Headless browser control
  • Form filling and clicking
  • Screenshot capture

docs.title: Python Scaffold
docs.text: Generated projects follow a clean 3-layer architecture inspired by Domain-Driven Design.

docs.title: Architecture Overview
docs.text:
graph TB
    subgraph Presentation["Presentation Layer"]
        API[REST API<br/>FastAPI]
        CLI[CLI<br/>Typer]
    end

    subgraph Services["Services Layer"]
        SVC[Application Services]
    end

    subgraph Domain["Domain Layer"]
        ENT[Entities]
        REPO_INT[Repository Interfaces]
    end

    subgraph Adapters["Adapters Layer"]
        REPO_IMPL[Repository Implementations]
    end

    API --> SVC
    CLI --> SVC
    SVC --> ENT
    SVC --> REPO_INT
    REPO_INT -.-> REPO_IMPL

docs.title: Package Structure
docs.text:
src/my_project/
├── __init__.py              # Package root, version
├── domain/                  # Core business logic
│   ├── __init__.py
│   └── entities.py          # Domain entities
├── adapters/                # Infrastructure implementations
│   ├── __init__.py
│   └── repositories/        # Data access
│       └── __init__.py
├── services/                # Application orchestration
│   └── __init__.py
├── api/                     # REST API presentation
│   ├── __init__.py
│   └── main.py              # FastAPI application
├── cli/                     # CLI presentation
│   ├── __init__.py
│   └── main.py              # Typer application
└── infrastructure/          # Cross-cutting concerns
    ├── __init__.py
    └── config.py            # Configuration

docs.title: Domain Layer
docs.text:
The heart of your application - pure business logic.

@dataclass(frozen=True)
class ExampleEntity(EntityBase):
    """Domain entity with business rules."""
    name: str
    description: str = ""

    def is_valid(self) -> bool:
        return len(self.name) > 0

Key principles:

  • Entities are immutable (frozen=True)
  • No external dependencies
  • Contains business rules
  • Defines repository interfaces

docs.title: Services Layer
docs.text:
Application orchestration - coordinates domain objects.

class ExampleService:
    def __init__(self, repository: ExampleRepository) -> None:
        self._repository = repository

    async def create(self, name: str, description: str = "") -> ExampleEntity:
        if not name.strip():
            raise ValueError("Name cannot be empty")
        entity = ExampleEntity(name=name.strip(), description=description)
        return await self._repository.save(entity)

Key principles:

  • Depends only on domain layer
  • Validates input
  • Coordinates operations
  • Handles transactions

docs.title: Adapters Layer
docs.text:
Infrastructure implementations - database access, external APIs.

class InMemoryExampleRepository(ExampleRepository):
    def __init__(self) -> None:
        self._storage: dict[UUID, ExampleEntity] = {}

    async def save(self, entity: ExampleEntity) -> ExampleEntity:
        self._storage[entity.id] = entity
        return entity

Key principles:

  • Implements domain interfaces
  • Contains infrastructure details
  • Easily swappable

docs.title: Presentation Layer
docs.text: Two interfaces are provided out of the box:

docs.title: REST API (FastAPI)
docs.text:
@app.post("/entities", response_model=EntityResponse)
async def create_entity(
    request: CreateEntityRequest,
    service: ExampleService = Depends(get_example_service),
) -> Any:
    entity = await service.create(request.name, request.description)
    return EntityResponse(id=entity.id, name=entity.name, ...)

docs.title: CLI (Typer)
docs.text:
@app.command()
def create(
    name: str = typer.Argument(...),
    description: str = typer.Option("", "-d"),
) -> None:
    entity = run_async(service.create(name, description))
    console.print(f"Created: {entity.id}")

docs.title: Dependency Flow
docs.text:
Presentation → Services → Domain ← Adapters

The Domain has no dependencies. Everything points toward it, not away from it.

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text: Benefit How It's Achieved Testability Mock adapters, test services in isolation Maintainability Changes are localized to specific layers Flexibility Swap databases without changing business logic Clarity Clear boundaries, obvious where code belongs

docs.title: Adding a New Entity
docs.text:
1. Create in domain/entities.py:
@dataclass(frozen=True)
class Product(EntityBase):
    name: str
    price: Decimal
  1. Add repository interface in adapters/repositories/
  2. Create service in services/
  3. Add API endpoints in api/
  4. Add CLI commands in cli/

docs.title: Adding a Database
docs.text:
1. Create a new repository implementation:
class PostgresExampleRepository(ExampleRepository):
    def __init__(self, session: AsyncSession):
        self._session = session
    # ... implement methods
  1. Update dependency injection to use it

The domain and services remain unchanged!

docs.title: Dev Containers
docs.text: Generated projects include full VS Code Dev Container support for consistent, reproducible development environments.

docs.title: What are Dev Containers?
docs.text:
Dev Containers run your entire development environment inside a Docker container, ensuring:

  • Consistency - Same environment for all developers
  • Isolation - Dependencies don't pollute your host system
  • Reproducibility - "Works on my machine" becomes "works everywhere"

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
1. Docker Desktop installed and running
  2. VS Code with the Dev Containers extension

docs.title: 1. Open in VS Code
docs.text:
cd my-project
code .

docs.title: 2. Reopen in Container
docs.text:
When VS Code detects the .devcontainer folder, you'll see a prompt:

Folder contains a Dev Container configuration file. Reopen folder to develop in a container.

Click "Reopen in Container".

Alternatively:

  1. Press Cmd+Shift+P (Mac) or Ctrl+Shift+P (Windows/Linux)
  2. Type "Dev Containers: Reopen in Container"
  3. Press Enter

docs.title: 3. Wait for Build
docs.text:
The first build takes a few minutes as it:

  • Pulls the base Python image
  • Installs system dependencies
  • Installs Python packages
  • Sets up MCP servers

Subsequent opens are much faster.

docs.title: Justfile Commands
docs.text: All available commands in generated projects.

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: just --list  # Show all commands

docs.title: install
docs.text:
Install all dependencies including dev tools.

just install
# Runs: uv sync --all-extras

docs.title: install-prod
docs.text:
Install only production dependencies.

just install-prod
# Runs: uv sync

docs.title: serve
docs.text:
Start the API server.

just serve
just serve --port 3000  # With arguments

docs.title: dev
docs.text:
Start development server with auto-reload.

just dev
# Runs: uvicorn my_project.api.main:app --reload

docs.title: cli
docs.text:
Run CLI commands.

just cli --help
just cli version
just cli create "My Entity" -d "Description"

docs.title: check
docs.text:
Run all quality checks (lint, typecheck, test).

just check

docs.title: lint
docs.text:
Run Ruff linter.

just lint
# Runs: uv run ruff check src/ tests/

docs.title: lint-fix
docs.text:
Fix linting issues automatically.

just lint-fix
# Runs: uv run ruff check src/ tests/ --fix

docs.title: format
docs.text:
Format code with Ruff.

just format
# Runs: uv run ruff format src/ tests/

docs.title: format-check
docs.text:
Check formatting without changes.

just format-check

docs.title: typecheck
docs.text:
Run MyPy type checker.

just typecheck
# Runs: uv run mypy src/

docs.title: security
docs.text:
Run Bandit security scanner.

just security
# Runs: uv run bandit -r src/

docs.title: test
docs.text:
Run all tests.

just test
just test -v              # Verbose
just test tests/unit/     # Specific directory

docs.title: test-cov
docs.text:
Run tests with coverage report.

just test-cov
# Generates terminal and HTML reports

docs.title: test-watch
docs.text:
Run tests in watch mode.

just test-watch
# Requires pytest-watch

docs.title: test-unit
docs.text:
Run only unit tests.

just test-unit

docs.title: test-integration
docs.text:
Run only integration tests.

just test-integration

docs.title: docs-serve
docs.text:
Serve documentation locally.

just docs-serve
# Opens http://localhost:8000

docs.title: docs-build
docs.text:
Build static documentation.

just docs-build
# Output in site/

docs.title: docs-deploy
docs.text:
Deploy to GitHub Pages.

just docs-deploy
# Runs: mkdocs gh-deploy --force

docs.title: docs-check
docs.text:
Build with strict mode to catch errors.

just docs-check

docs.title: build
docs.text:
Build the package.

just build
# Runs: uv build
# Output in dist/

docs.title: clean
docs.text:
Remove build artifacts.

just clean
# Removes: build/, dist/, __pycache__, etc.

docs.title: version
docs.text:
Show current version.

just version
# From hatch-vcs (git tags)

docs.title: docker-build
docs.text:
Build Docker image.

just docker-build

docs.title: docker-run
docs.text:
Run Docker container.

just docker-run

docs.title: up
docs.text:
Start all services with Docker Compose.

just up

docs.title: down
docs.text:
Stop all services.

just down

docs.title: logs
docs.text:
View container logs.

just logs
just logs app -f  # Follow specific service

docs.title: db-up
docs.text:
Start database services.

just db-up

docs.title: db-down
docs.text:
Stop database services.

just db-down

docs.title: save
docs.text:
Quick commit all changes.

just save "commit message"
# Runs: git add -A && git commit -m "message"

docs.title: undo
docs.text:
Undo last commit (keep changes).

just undo
# Runs: git reset --soft HEAD~1

docs.title: Customizing
docs.text:
Edit justfile to add your own commands:

# My custom command
deploy:
    ssh server "cd /app && git pull && docker compose up -d"
